MOTION FOR SUSPENSION OF MEMBER
(Ruling by Mr Speaker)


2.31 p.m.

    Mr Speaker: In relation to the motion in regard to the Member for Hong Lim which was sought to be moved by the Leader of the House yesterday, hon. Members will now know that notice of the motion had in fact been given. The notice was to the effect that the Leader of the House would move the motion on Monday, the 19th day of December, 1960.

    The Leader of the House nevertheless appeared to have taken the view that the motion was of such urgency and of such importance that he was compelled to bring the matter to the House for debate immediately relying on the provisions of paragraph (e) of Standing Order No. 30 which reads as follows:-

    `30. Unless Standing Orders otherwise direct, notice shall be given of any motion which it is proposed to move with the exception of the following:-

    (e) A motion for the suspension of a Member.

    Hon. Members will recollect that I stated that I wished to be satisfied on two points before I permitted the Leader of the House to proceed, the two points being, firstly, whether in view of the fact that yesterday was a day allotted for the business of Supply, the motion could be taken on such a day and, secondly, whether the motion could properly be moved without notice under the provisions of paragraph (e) of Standing Order No. 30.

Column: 674



    On the first point, the relevant Standing Order as I indicated yesterday is Standing Order No. 85, paragraph (2) of which reads as follows:-

    `(2) On a day allotted to the business of Supply, the business of Supply shall stand as the first order, and so long as the business of Supply has not been completed, no business other than the business of Supply shall be taken after 3 p.m. or before 8 p.m., and except in pursuance of Standing Order No. 21 (Adjournment on a definite matter of urgent public importance) no business of Supply shall be taken after 8 p.m., whether an order exempting business from interruption under Standing Order No. 4 (Exempted Business) is in force or not, unless the Assembly otherwise orders on the motion of a Minister moved at any time between 7 p.m. and 7.30 p.m. to be decided without amendment or debate.'

    I think that there can be no doubt that a motion of the nature proposed to be moved by the Leader of the House is an item of business within the meaning of the term "business" used in paragraph (2) of Standing Order No. 85, and therefore under the terms of that paragraph, the motion could not be taken on any day allotted for the business of Supply between 3 p.m. and 8 p.m. but could be taken before 3 p.m. and/or after 8 p.m., in the latter case, upon a resolution under the provisions of paragraph (1) of Standing Order No. 4 that the proceedings thereon be exempted from the provisions of Standing Order No. 1 (Sittings of the Assembly), in order that the motion could be debated after the moment of interruption.

    On the second point, the question of notice, it is a well established principle of Parliamentary practice that before a complaint is made against a Member he should be given notice beforehand in order that he should know the substance of the charge against him and in order that he may be given the opportunity of being in the House in his place to be heard, if he so desired, in explanation or exculpation. When, however, a Member is guilty of an offence in the view of the Assembly, that is to say, guilty of an offence committed by him while he is in the House during its sitting, and it is thought necessary to take action against him immediately, then, of course,

Column: 675

no such notice would be necessary, and proceedings could be taken against him forthwith.

    Bearing in mind the principle I have enunciated, therefore, it appears to me that the provision in Standing Order No. 30 whereby a motion for the suspension of a Member could be moved without notice must be taken, in fairness to the Member concerned, to have reference to a case where the Member is guilty of an offence in the view of the Assembly. In such an event, the Standing Orders themselves provide for the procedure to be followed. The relevant Standing Order is Standing Order No. 56, paragraph (1) of which reads:

    `56. -(1) Whenever a Member has been named by the Speaker or by the Chairman, immediately after the commission of the offence of disregarding the authority of the Chair, or of persistently and wilfully obstructing the business of the Assembly by abusing the rules of the Assembly, or otherwise, then, if the offence has been committed by such Member in the Assembly a motion shall forthwith be proposed by a Minister or Parliamentary Secretary present "That Mr... be suspended from the service of the Assembly", and the Speaker shall forthwith put the question on that motion, no amendment, adjournment or debate being allowed; and, if the offence has been committed in Committee of the whole Assembly, the Chairman shall forthwith suspend the proceedings of the Committee and report the circumstances to the Assembly; and the Speaker shall on a motion being made as aforesaid forthwith put the same question, no amendment, adjournment or debate being allowed, as if the offence had been committed in the Assembly itself.'

    I have formed the opinion, therefore, that the motion for the suspension of a Member mentioned in paragraph (e) of Standing Order No. 30 must be taken to refer to the motion to suspend described in the paragraph I have quoted.

    Apart from what I have said the motion proposed to be moved by the Leader of the House is, of course, more than merely a motion to suspend the Member for Hong Lim. It also seeks a resolution of the House condemning the Member for Hong Lim for certain conduct alleged, in the motion, to be dishonourable and unbecoming of an elected representative of the people.

Column: 676



    All in all, therefore, it is my considered opinion that this matter is clearly a matter which calls for appropriate notice to be given not only to the hon. Member concerned but also to other hon. Members of the House. I therefore rule that the motion cannot be proceeded with forthwith and does require the requisite notice.

    On the notice already given, the motion will accordingly be set down for Monday, 19th of December.

    Head D8 -

    That the sum to be allocated for Head D8 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 1.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the provision is for two purposes, both in the City and rural areas. These two purposes are as follows:

Column: 677



    (1) Section 15 of the Planning Ordinance provides for the service of purchase notices on Government in cases:-

    `(a) where any person whose land is allocated in the Master Plan for development for a public purpose (other than a green belt) completes development of any contiguous land belonging to him. He can serve a purchase notice on the Government.'

2.45 p.m.

    For example, the owners of housing estates, after completion of development, can serve purchase notices in respect of land within the estate which has been zoned on the Master Plan as "public open space" or for a "public market". Or,

    `(b) where any person has been refused permission to develop land allocated under the Master Plan for a public purpose (other than a green belt) in an area where permission would otherwise have been granted to such development of land.'

    I can give another relevant example. The Geylang Serai Trade Fair site. Here we refused permission for development of part of the site as a private market, and the owner could have served a purchase notice in this case.

    The sum provided in the Estimates will enable the Government to purchase land in such cases.

    (2) The sum is also to enable acquisitions for improvement schemes, back-lanes and roundabouts to be carried out, and to meet outstanding liabilities under the Singapore Improvement Ordinance.

    The Parliamentary Secretary did mention - I do not know whether the interpretation was correct - that Geylang Serai, which is my constituency, is within the scheme of the slum clearance. Can he confirm that?

It may well be for divers reasons that the priorities which we are giving at this moment may not be the priorities which will, in fact, be implemented. I do not think it will be practical or wise to name the priorities at this stage.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, I agree with the statement of the Prime Minister that perhaps it might not be wise to divulge the areas where the Government wishes to go in and buy land, but at least he could tell the House how much of this money is for land acquisition and how much of it is for improvement schemes. Is the Government saying that if any owner of property in the green belt wishes the Government to compensate him for loss of use, this vote will be used for such compensation?

The item has been included under the Development Estimates because, as I have explained, such items in the past would have been in the Rural Board Development vote. discharge these duties, and for this reason has been asked to do so, is the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development.     Head D13 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head D13 be reduced by $100.

    Sir, hon. Members are aware that the Federation Government is going ahead with an international airport of its own. In the light of that, does the Government not consider that the importance and usefulness of the Singapore Airport might be impaired to the extent that certain traffic might be diverted to the Federation International Airport? If such is the case, would not the Government think it advisable to reconsider its plans fur the development of the Paya Lebar Airport, and see in what way money could be saved, if necessary, before spending such a big sum, about $11 million, for an airport whose usefulness and importance might be impaired as the result of another international airport just 250 miles away?

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, we are fully aware that the Federation Government are very anxious to build their own international airport, thereby probably saving Federal citizens the trouble of coming down to Singapore to catch a flight overseas. However, I would like

Column: 685

to remind the House, and in particular the Member for Cairnhill, that even if the Federation should have their own international airport, a considerable amount of air traffic will still pass through Singapore. We are in the privileged position that we have an international airport located almost within eyeview of the seaport. With such a favourable location, it is important that Singapore should seek not to diminish but to increase its prestige as an international communication centre.

    The plans for development of the international airport at Paya Lebar have been thoroughly studied by me when the Department came under my control. Estimates made in 1959 to spend $60 million on development on the Paya Lebar Airport have since been considerably cut down. The requirements for a hangar runway extension and passenger terminal building amount to only $6.5 million. The amount of money spent on these facilities should be clearly distinguished from that spent for telecommunications. The amount for telecommunications is $2.2 million.

    It is important that in these days, when jet planes are flying at a speed of about 400 to 600 miles per hour, we should be able to detect these planes several miles before they arrive at Singapore.

3.15 p.m.

    It is, in fact, one of the functions of Air Traffic Control to direct aircraft at what altitude and at what distance they should fly into Singapore. Without telecommunications, it will not be possible to do so. And in Singapore we are particularly faced with the problem of co-ordinating civil and military aircraft. As Members are aware, there are altogether four airfields in Singapore - one civil airfield and three military airfields, the military airfields being at Changi, Tengah and Seletar. Military aircraft are jet-powered aircraft. Civil aircraft today are also jet-powered aircraft. Changi airfield is very close to Paya Lebar airfield, and it has happened at

Column: 686

times that military aircraft have mistaken the civil aerodrome as Changi airfield and vice versa. Under these conditions, it is essential that no accidents and no collisions should occur between fast flying aircraft, and the only way to prevent these collisions is to use the latest technological advances in telecommunications.

    We do not have radar aid, and it is proposed to install radar costing $1.1 million at Paya Lebar to assist Air Traffic Control.

    We have been very careful in estimating demands for extension of the runway. Let me inform the House that there are two considerations in the building of the runway. One is strength and the other is length. As far as the strength of the Paya Lebar runway is concerned, all airline operators are satisfied that its structural strength fulfils their requirements.

    At a meeting of the International Civil Aviation Organisation in January 1959 in Rome, there was some form of general consensus of opinion that the runway for all airfields where the first generation jets, the Boeing 707 and the D.C.8. will be landing, should have at least a length of 9,500 feet. In January this year, the International Air Transport Association -I.A.T.A. -reviewed the position, and considered that there should be, in fact, a length of 10,000 feet, plus 500 feet clear-way at each end, totalling 11,000 feet. In February this year, a Pan-American Airways jet survey team came to Paya Lebar to examine the facilities of the airport. It came to the conclusion that the runway at Paya Lebar was adequate for existing sector lengths, although it may be insufficient for full economic operation where the stage lengths of the Boeing 707 aircraft exceed 1,500 miles. All aircraft which fly from Singapore have a range of 1,500 miles. Djakarta, Bangkok. Manila, Saigon, Rangoon, Ceylon, Hongkong and Calcutta, all these airports are within 1,500 miles. The only sector on which the Boeing 707 does not carry a full pay-load is the Singapore-Darwin sector; this sector having a distance of 1,820 miles.

Column: 687



    As Members can see, there are conflicting views on runway requirements by different airline operators, depending upon the type of aircraft they used. We have today the first generation jets in the Comet, the Boeing 707 and the D.C.8. It has been predicted that in 1964 the second generation jets will appear. One of them is the V.C.10, and it has been stated by the manufacturers that the V.C.10 will be able to utilise the Paya Lebar Airport on the existing length of 8,000 feet on full pay-load from Karachi to Singapore. In 10 to 15 years' time, it is predicted in the technical journals that supersonic aircraft will make their appearance. As aircraft designs improve and as aircraft engines improve, the length of runway for take-off need not be as long as is the demand made by the airline operators today. In fact, at the Farnborough air show this year, it was reported that an experimental aircraft came flying in, stopped in mid-air, and landed down vertically.

    Mr Speaker, when we consider the requirements and the developments of the airport, we have to look pretty far ahead, and we have to keep in touch with modern developments. We should not, therefore, consider developments just for next year or the year after. We should consider what will happen to the developments that we put up now at the airport in five years' time, in ten years' time.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I have said, Mr Speaker, that we have made a careful study of the development of Paya Lebar Airport, and the amount of money that has been allocated for its future development has been scaled down considerably from the original estimates. Moreover, we are encouraged by the promise of the United Kingdom Government to assist in the development at Paya Lebar. In a letter from the

Secretary of State to the Prime Minister, he has promised £210,000 sterling for runway extension; £296,700 for radar and other telecommunication aids; and £250,000 for a terminal building. It does not necessarily mean that if you have an international airport at Kuala Lumpur, therefore we should close down the Paya Lebar Airport. I am sure the Member for Cairnhill is not suggesting that. Moreover, I may add that airline operators will continue to pass through Singapore in five years, ten years time, whatever may happen in other parts of South-East Asia; for one simple reason, and that is, Singapore is the centre for air traffic.
